content.description: This little gem starts with a long jump to the opening holds (if you're short). The crux section is a bit hard to decipher at first as most of the holds are slopers. A little feeling around will eventually uncover two small edges. The second crux comes at the top and also involves large white slopers. Unfortunately there are no edges to find up here. Try to hang on long enough to get the anchors clipped.
content.location: First route on the right side of the cliff.

content.description: This is the best route on the cliff. Thin technical climbing leads to a decent rest. The crux moves come at the top and involve a long lunge to a good edge.
content.location: 2nd route in from the right side

content.description: Thin powerful climbing on small crimps will get you to the diagonaling rail. From there more of the usual slopers to the chains. This one may be a bit harder if you're short.
Easy slab leads to a pumpy crux in the middle of the route. There's a nice ledge to catch a rest about 3/4 of the way up. Don't be fooled the top is still technical and slopey.
content.location: 4th route from the right side of the cliff.

content.description: Another fun route on the numbers crag.  Start by scrambling up some easy rock to a double hueco feature with some big holds to clip the first bolt.  The first hard sequence comes at mid height requiring a bit of a big move.  From there continue up to a technical finish.  There really isn't much of a finishing hold to clip the anchors, so clip then when you can.
content.location: Between Number 1 and Number 3, look for the double hueco feature that is just below the first bolt

climbs.name: Number 1
climbs.fa: Sal Mamusia, Paul Van Betten, Richard Harrison 1992

content.description: Start below shelf, continue up the wall past a horizontal into a bulging seam which is followed to a hard-to-see anchor.
left side of crag on very steep, scooped wall covered in shallow pockets.

This sunny cliff see relative little activity. Since the addition of anchors on all but one route it is a nice alternative crag for winter climbing when all the old standbys are crowded. Some of the top outs are a bit dicey but it is easy to walk to the top and set up a top rope.
